title: Taxpayers to cover $60M in Cleveland stadium renos
text:
Taxpayers to cover $60M in Cleveland stadium renos Northeast Ohio Media Group 2:42 p.m. EDT October 15, 2015 Sep 29, 2015; Cleveland, OH, USA; A general view of Progressive Field during a rain delay of a game between the Cleveland Indians and the Minnesota Twins. Mandatory Credit: David Richard-USA TODAY Sports (Photo: David Richard-USA TODAY Sports) CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
CLEVELAND (AP) — Officials say Cuyahoga County is preparing to foot the bill for just over $60 million worth of repairs and upgrades to the homes of both the Cleveland Indians and Cavaliers. 
Northeast Ohio Media Group reports (http://bit.ly/1k6dCIi) the northeast Ohio county is required to cover the cost of renovations per its leases with Cleveland's professional baseball and basketball franchises. 
Among the repairs includes a new scoreboard for the Indians at Progressive Field and a new roof for the Cavaliers' Quicken Loans Arena. 
County Executive Armond Budish has sponsored legislation introduced Tuesday that would cover expenses through the sale of $65 million in bonds to be repaid by Cuyahoga County's 20-year tax on alcohol and cigarettes. 
Distribution of the so-called "sin tax" is expected to raise $260 million for Cleveland's sports arenas.
